question.title: Does a Java app always require com.apple.security.cs.allow-jit to run in App Sandbox (Mac)?
question.body:
I'm working on a Java-based Mac app that embeds JVM runtime inside (e.g. libjvm.dylib).

It seems to me that libjvm.dylib requires JIT. Without the entitlement, the app would crash at the start at the pthread_jit_write_protect_np method invocation. Here's the crash report:

Thread 2 Crashed:
0   libsystem_pthread.dylib              0x199b30bdc pthread_jit_write_protect_np + 520
1   libjvm.dylib                         0x103301178 Threads::create_vm(JavaVMInitArgs*, bool*) + 184 (threads.cpp:430)
2   libjvm.dylib                         0x1030ddfc0 JNI_CreateJavaVM_inner(JavaVM_**, void**, void*) + 80 (jni.cpp:3577) [inlined]
3   libjvm.dylib                         0x1030ddfc0 JNI_CreateJavaVM + 116 (jni.cpp:3668)
4   libjli.dylib                         0x102452904 InitializeJVM + 200 (java.c:1506) [inlined]
5   libjli.dylib                         0x102452904 JavaMain + 264 (java.c:415)
6   libjli.dylib                         0x10245580c ThreadJavaMain + 12 (java_md_macosx.m:720)
7   libsystem_pthread.dylib              0x199b2fc0c _pthread_start + 136
8   libsystem_pthread.dylib              0x199b2ab80 thread_start + 8

I also tried building a JDK with no JIT (i.e. the variant zero), but the app still crashes.

I have one specific question: Does this mean a Java-based Mac app will always require the com.apple.security.cs.allow-jit entitlement to run in App Sandbox?

answers.body:
I've got the answer from the java dev mailing list.

A Java app will always need com.apple.security.cs.allow-jit because, according to the JIT definition of Mac i.e. never generate and run code on-the-fly, Java uses JIT.

But the definition of JIT in Java means to use the JVM features: compiler1 and compiler2.

Here's the link to the thread: https://mail.openjdk.org/pipermail/hotspot-dev/2025-October/112936.html
